faqs.question: Why is there such a big price range ($5K-75K)?
faqs.answer: Complexity drives cost. Simple appointment booking with calendar integration is $5K-15K. Healthcare system with HIPAA compliance, EHR integration, multi-workflow is $50K-75K. Most projects fall in $15K-35K range.

faqs.question: What determines if I need the $15K vs $35K vs $75K solution?
faqs.answer: Three factors: (1) Number of integrations - each adds $2K-5K, (2) Compliance requirements - HIPAA/PCI adds $10K-15K, (3) Complexity - simple booking vs multi-step workflows. We can estimate in 30-min consultation.

faqs.question: Are monthly costs really that low ($300-600)?
faqs.answer: Yes, for typical volume (500-1,000 calls/month). Voice AI pricing is per-minute. If your volume 10x increases, monthly costs increase proportionally. We design for your expected volume + 30% buffer.

faqs.question: What's NOT included in these prices?
faqs.answer: Prices include build, deploy, initial training. NOT included: major feature additions after launch, 24/7 support (we offer during business hours), ongoing optimization (we include first 30 days). Extended support packages available.

faqs.question: How do you compare to other agencies/platforms?
faqs.answer: We're mid-range. DIY platforms ($500-2K/year but you build it) are cheaper upfront but require technical skills. Big agencies ($100K+ projects) have overhead. We focus on $15K-50K sweet spot: custom but efficient.

faqs.question: Can I get exact pricing for MY project?
faqs.answer: Yes. Schedule 30-min consultation. We'll ask about your workflow, integrations needed, compliance requirements, and volume. Then provide detailed estimate with line-item breakdown. No obligation.

name: Build vs Buy: AI Cost Comparison
metaTitle: Build vs Buy AI: Complete Cost Comparison 2025 | POSTMAN
metaDescription: Should you build AI in-house or hire an agency? Complete cost breakdown: engineer salaries, time to market, opportunity cost. Real numbers from 30+ companies.
heroH1: Build vs Buy AI: Complete Cost Comparison 2025
heroSubtext: Should you build in-house or hire an agency? Real cost breakdown including engineer salaries, time to market, and opportunity cost most companies ignore.
problemStatement: 'We'll just have our developers build it' sounds cheaper. But is it? Factor in salaries, time to market, opportunity cost, and ongoing maintenance. Here's the math.

buildInHouse.name: Build In-House
pros: Full control over code and architecture
cons: Opportunity cost: Engineers not building core product
buildInHouse.bestFor: Companies with: (1) Budget for dedicated AI team, (2) Long-term AI strategy needing multiple projects, (3) Strategic AI capabilities (core to business)

hireAgency.name: Hire Agency (POSTMAN)
pros: No hiring risk or ramp-up time
Your team stays focused on core product
cons: Dependency on agency for major changes
IP shared (though you own the code)
May cost more long-term if many iterations needed
hireAgency.bestFor: Companies with: (1) Need solution quickly (3-8 weeks), (2) Don't want AI team overhead, (3) Want to validate use case before big investment

saasplatform.name: Buy SaaS Platform
cons: Per-usage pricing can get expensive at scale
saasplatform.bestFor: Companies with: (1) Simple use case (basic booking, FAQs), (2) Want to test concept quickly, (3) No custom integration requirements, (4) Small volume (< 1,000 interactions/month)

decisionFramework.scenario: You need AI solution in next 1-2 months
decisionFramework.reason: Building in-house takes 6-12 months. SaaS if your use case is very simple.

decisionFramework.reason: Team can reuse learnings across projects. Agency cost adds up (3 x $25K = $75K, close to one engineer).
Cheapest way to validate. If limitations hit, upgrade to custom (agency or in-house).
SaaS platforms rarely handle complex compliance. Agency if need quickly, in-house if strategic.
Can't hire engineer for $50K. Agency gives you solution + expertise within budget.

decisionFramework.scenario: AI is core to your business strategy
decisionFramework.reason: Strategic capabilities stay in-house. Consider agency for MVP, build team after validation.

realWorldExample.situation: Needed patient appointment scheduling automation. Debated build vs buy.

option1.result: Worked well but 9 months = missed revenue opportunity. Engineer left after 1 year.

option2.result: Launched faster, saved $180K year 1, proved value before building team.

realWorldExample.decision: They chose agency (us). After validating with customers (6 months), hired AI engineer to build v2 with more features. Hybrid approach worked perfectly.

faqs.question: Isn't it always cheaper to build in-house long-term?
faqs.answer: Not necessarily. If you need 1-2 AI features, agency is cheaper ($30K-60K total vs $200K/year for engineer). If you need 5+ features over 2 years, in-house becomes cheaper. Most companies overestimate how much AI they'll build.

faqs.question: What if we hire agency then want to take over later?
faqs.answer: Perfect approach. We hand off clean code, documentation, and train your team. Many clients do: agency for MVP (prove value fast), hire engineer after validation to expand features. We support this.

faqs.question: Can we do a hybrid (agency builds, we maintain)?
faqs.answer: Yes! Common model: We build (3-8 weeks), hand off code, your engineers handle minor updates. We stay available for major features/fixes. Saves you maintenance cost ($300-1K/month) if you have technical team.

faqs.question: How do I know if my use case is too simple for custom build?
faqs.answer: If your workflow is: (1) Single integration, (2) No compliance requirements, (3) Template conversation flow, (4) < 500 interactions/month â†’ Try SaaS first. Everything else benefits from custom.

faqs.question: What's the 'opportunity cost' you mention?
faqs.answer: If your engineers spend 6 months building AI instead of core product, what revenue did you miss? If core product generates $50K/month and AI delays launch 6 months, opportunity cost is $300K. Factor this into 'build' decision.

faqs.question: What would YOU recommend for most companies?
faqs.answer: Honest answer: Agency for first AI project (prove value fast, low risk). If it works and you want more AI features, hire in-house team or keep using agency for speed. Don't hire AI engineer before proving the use case works.
